docs.lead_paragraph: The American Heritage Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Columbia Universal Corporation of Austin, Tex., for $44 million in cash. American Heritage said the acquisition would result in an increase in operating earnings per share. Columbia Universal, with assets of $360 million, is a privately held provider of annuity, supplemental health and individual life insurance products through a subsidiary, the Columbia Universal Life Insurance Company.

headline.main: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE TO BUY COLUMBIA UNIVERSAL

docs.abstract: American Heritage Life Insurance Co agrees in principle to acquire Columbia Universal Corp for $44 million cash (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer M. did not drink much in the mornings, maybe a swig of vodka at home or a beer on her way to school, just enough to make a teen-age alcoholic feel that she could face the day. ''I'd wake up in the morning, I'd be depressed,'' said Jennifer, who is 17. ''I couldn't even go to school unless I had a drink.''
docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund drive continues; help given by Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services to teen-age alcoholic in Brooklyn discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When it was created in the 1960's, Medicare gave the elderly the same fee-for-service coverage that everyone else used. But now Medicare stands nearly alone in providing this most expensive health-care choice, at huge taxpayer expense. One result has been a growing consensus among ideologically diverse people that the structure of Medicare must change. The list of reformers includes Nancy Johnson, a House Republican from Connecticut; Ron Wyden, a Senate Democrat from Oregon; the Brookings Institution, a liberal-leaning think tank, and the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think thank. The latest addition to the list is the American Medical Association, the physicians' group that tried to scuttle Medicare at its inception.
docs.abstract: Editorial sees growing consensus among ideologically diverse people that stucture of Medicare must change, noting that Medicare stands nearly alone in providing fee-for-service coverage--most expensive health-care choice--at huge taxpayer expense; sees some laudable aspects to American Medical Assn's proposal, which mirrors market-based system that gives millions of Federal employees a wide choice of health plans
docs.snippet: When it was created in the 1960's, Medicare gave the elderly the same fee-for-service coverage that everyone else used. But now Medicare stands nearly alone in providing this most expensive health-care choice, at huge taxpayer expense.    One result...

docs.lead_paragraph: Beth Israel Medical Center and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center announced yesterday that they were forming a single parent corporation to oversee both hospitals, another shift in the realignment of the health care industry in New York City. The partnership between the two hospitals is not a merger -- each will maintain its own board of trustees and clinical departments and will be responsible for its own assets and debts. But it is the latest example of how hospitals have been forced to find creative ways of joining forces to enhance their bargaining positions with health maintenance organizations, which increasingly control where Americans get their care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Japan's corporate profits rose an average 12.7 percent in the July-September quarter compared with the corresponding period in 1995, the Ministry of Finance said yesterday. While the quarterly rise in pretax profits was the ninth consecutive increase, it was the smallest growth in a year. The data also showed that Japan's economic recovery has not broadened, since profits fell in a number of industries.

headline.main: Japan Corporate Profits Up 12.7% in Quarter

docs.abstract: Japan reports corporate pretax profits rose average 12.7 percent, July-Sept, from 1995 period; profits fell in number of industries, indicating economic recovery has not broadened (S)
docs.snippet: Japan's corporate profits rose an average 12.7 percent in the July-September quarter compared with the corresponding period in 1995, the Ministry of Finance said yesterday. While the quarterly rise in pretax profits was the ninth consecutive...

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, most foreign patients at the New England Medical Center were wealthy Europeans and Latin Americans. But now a patient from overseas is more likely to be someone like Gladys Soto Pilone, a 62-year-old retired schoolteacher, whose health plan in Argentina agreed to pay for breast cancer surgery in Boston last summer. Reaching beyond their longstanding international clientele of royal potentates, celebrities and wealthy people, top-drawer medical centers including the Mayo Clinic, the Texas Heart Institute, the Cleveland Clinic and New England Medical are helping to fill their beds and pay their bills by wooing groups of less affluent foreign patients.

headline.main: Hospitals Looking Abroad To Keep Their Beds Filled

docs.abstract: Top medical centers, reaching beyond longstanding international clientele of royalty, celebrities and rich are wooing less affluent patients to fill their beds; push has led hundreds of research and teaching institutions to create package deals and offer other inducements to attract private and government health plans in Latin America and Middle East, as well as small but growing of patients from Pacific Rim; hospitals are looking abroad because of changes sweeping through medical establishment at home; already squeezed by managed care and reduced government payments, many are having difficulty recruiting enough patients to support elaborate high-technology programs; competition has grown so heated that some Middle Eastern health officials have begun to bargain for better deals, playing one American hospital against another; both sides; for hard-pressed hospital budgets, rewards of recruiting foreign patients, measured in tens of millions of dollars, can be crucial; average fee for American patients at some medical centers is $8,000, but for foreign patients who usually come for much more serious problems, average ranges between $20,000 to $30,000; for most part, payments from foreign patients are free from limitations imposed on many American patients by managed care organizations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A medical equipment company has offered to pay $112 million to settle claims by thousands of patients who said the pain in their backs worsened after surgeons inserted steel screws and plates intended to help them. Some patients said the screws broke inside their spines. Lawyers for the plaintiffs said the agreement, announced by Acromed, a company founded by a Cleveland doctor who invented the screw-and-plate device, would be a precedent for agreements in dozens of lawsuits involving 17 manufacturers.

headline.main: $112 Million Offered to End Legal Claims On Spine Pins

docs.abstract: Acromed, medical equipment company, offers to pay $112 million to settle claims by thousands of patients who say pain in backs worsened after surgeons inserted steel screws and plates intended to help them; says it still believes claims in lawsuits are without merit (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NO one knows yet whether the Columbus Circle redevelopment project will wind up as a Sears or Sotheby's, a Reebok health spa or the Museum of American Folk Art, a swank hotel or a high-priced condominium apartment tower. But there is one safe bet. It will almost certainly wind up in court. With months to go before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority selects finalists from among competing proposals for the New York Coliseum site, the chorus of litigants is already warming up.
docs.abstract: Litigation is part of standard operating procedure for New York City real estate developments of any consequence; suits and threats of suits help shape strategy early in development process; project opponents need not win in court to derail or force major changes in projects; drawing; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The call came while Linda Corbett was in her yard gardening. A supervisor at Pacific Bell, a man she knew, told her that his staff was overwhelmed with work. He wanted to know whether Ms. Corbett would consider returning to the company from which, just six months earlier, she had been ''severed involuntarily,'' as she still puts it bitterly. Ms. Corbett, who is 42, resisted at first. She had reacted to her ouster by plunging into suburban life. She became active in the Chamber of Commerce, took courses in how to start a small business, gave parties with her husband and tended her vegetables and flowers. But she finally gave in, returning last May to a sales job at the company that had employed her since high school.

headline.main: More Downsized Workers Are Returning as Rentals

docs.abstract: Surveys show that employees who have been laid off or bought out by their employers are commonly being brought back as temporary or contract workers; as many as twenty percent of all contract workers, probably more than a million people, are downsized employees; some of these workers laud their new-found freedom, while others express bitterness and security worries; chart; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TRUE, stocks have risen more than 50 percent since the end of 1994. True, the July drop, so scary at the time, now looks like a blip. And true, November was the Dow's best month in five years, in points gained. But like squirrels before the frost, investors should be thinking about preparing for a chillier environment. And one need not be a worrywart to be worried: The market lost about 140 points last week. The economy is slowing, as will corporate earnings growth in 1997 and 1998. And history also bodes ill: Since the 1880's, the two years after a Presidential election have posted only 3 percent average annual gains for stocks, compared with 9 percent for the pre-election years.

headline.main: Where to Run if the Ceiling Starts to Crack

docs.abstract: Defensive stocks, those that hold up well in flat or declining markets, can provide good hedge for the day the soaring stock market begins to fall; chart of recommended stocks (M)
